- Trump's options to ease Russia sanctions limited compared to Europe's (Reuters). U.S. President Donald Trump could quickly lift some sanctions on Russia as a reward to Moscow if peace talks with Ukraine go well, but only Europe can take the bigger steps needed to significantly ease Russia's cash crunch. Trump in recent days has renewed a threat to impose more sanctions and tariffs on Russia and buyers of its oil if there is no progress toward a peaceful settlement in the 3-1/2-year-long war in Ukraine. But it talks go well, he could begin to lift some of the punitive measures. Among Trump's options are releasing seized Russian assets, reopening U.S. lending to Russian banks and corporations, and allowing U.S. oil services companies to return to Russia's far-flung oil and gas fields. Without Europe's cooperation, however, those measures would have limited effect and the most damaging sanctions - including massive restrictions on Russia's global oil trade, the lifeblood of its economy - would stay in place.

- Exxon sees natural gas demand surging in outlook to 2050 (Reuters). Global demand for natural gas will rise more than 20% by 2050 from last year's level, as it displaces coal to power industries and meet higher electricity use in developing countries, Exxon Mobil said on Thursday in an annual outlook. The projections provide the basis for the top U.S. oil producer's long-term strategy and investment. Exxon has ambitious growth plans compared to other global oil players, with a target to boost production by 18% over
the next five years.

Europe gas markets escape hectic LNG summer storage race (Reuters). European gas traders have faced a stressful race against the clock in recent summers as they have scrambled to refill depleted gas storage facilities ahead of winter. But with demand in Asian markets sagging, Europe can expect a surge of liquefied natural gas imports over the coming months, giving the continent's traders and governments a lot more breathing room. Ensuring that European gas supplies were at near- maximum levels before cold weather sets in was once a relatively niche concern, but it became a political imperative after the region sharply reduced pipeline gas imports from Russia following its invasion of Ukraine in 2022.

Italy's foreign minister sees no end to Ukraine war this year (Reuters). Russia's war of aggression on Ukraine is unlikely to end this year, Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said on Thursday. "The war isn't going to end as soon as some people said and believed ... I don't want to be a pessimist but I don't think there can be solutions before the end of the year," he said after a cabinet meeting in Rome. Tajani also said that "if Russia continues like this, it is clear there will have to be new sanctions".

Second German LNG terminal starts commercial operations at Wilhelmshaven (Reuters). Germany will officially start commercial operations at its second liquefied natural gas import terminal at Wilhelmshaven port on Aug 29., state operator Deutsche Energy Terminal said on Thursday, as the country diversifies its energy supply. In response to Moscow's invasion of Ukraine in 2022, Germany has turned to global, seaborne LNG to replace Russian gas supplied by pipelines on which it used to depend. It has also increased imports of pipeline gas from Norway.

Top FPSO contractor hungry for success after falling short on growth targets (Upstream). Norway's leading FPSO contractor is targeting three new contract wins by 2030 as part of a refreshed commitment to a sector where it has struggled to secure new contracts in recent years and faced execution challenges on the one project it did win. Oslo- based BW Offshore said in a results and strategy briefing that it met most of its goals for 2020 to 2024, including the divestment of 12 FPSOs from its fleet and the separation of BW Energy, which brought \(\) 632\(million of liquidity. However, it won only one floating production, storage and offloading vessel contract during the period, albeit an auspicious one.

References to "Bernstein" or the "Firm" in these disclosures relate to the following entities: Bernstein Institutional Services LLC (April 1, 2024 onwards), Sanford C. Bernstein & Co., LLC (pre April 1, 2024), Bernstein Autonomous LLP, BSG France S.A. (April 1, 2024 onwards), Sanford C. Bernstein (Hong Kong) Limited 盛博香港有限公司, Sanford C. Bernstein (Canada) Limited, Sanford C. Bernstein (India) Private Limited (SEBI registration no. INH000006378), Sanford C. Bernstein (Singapore) Private Limited and Sanford C. Bernstein Japan KK (サンフォード・C・バーンスタイン株式会社).

On April 1, 2024, Société Générale (SG) and AllianceBernstein, L.P. (AB) completed a transaction that created a new joint venture in which their respective cash equities and research businesses operate in a new business combination. Although their respective ownership percentages in the joint venture differ between North America and the rest of the world, the creation, production and publication of research is handled collaboratively on a global basis across the two research brands, "Bernstein" and "Autonomous". Unless specifically noted otherwise, for purposes of these disclosures, references to Bernstein's "affiliates" relate to both SG and AB and their respective affiliates.

The 510p BP PT is DCF derived; we assume Brent oil prices decline from c. \(\) 81\(in 2024 to\) \ \(65 / bbl\) in 2025 and 2026, with a long term flat nominal oil price of \(\) 70/ bbl\(with declining refining margins and an improvement / normalisation to chemicals margins. We further assume a\) 7.6\% \(WACC and - 0.2\%\) long term growth. We apply a 5% discount to the DCF value to arrive at the PT, so as to capture risks surrounding (a) BP's effort to transform into a low - carbon energy company (on future returns / value and cash / dividend generation), and (b) high commodity price volatility, versus what is our single point forecasts.

Our Eni PT of €15.5 assumes a WACC of \(8.5\%\) and \(- 0.5\%\) terminal- value growth. We assume that Brent oil prices decline from c. \(\) 81\(in 2024 to\) \ \(65 / bbl\) in 2025 and 2026, with a long term flat nominal oil price of \(\) 70/ bbl\(. We further factor in gradual long - term declines in returns and free cash generation under the unfolding energy transition. We typically set the 12 - month price target at a c.5% discount to the DCF value, as a subjective gesture aimed at reflecting: (a) unprecedented volatility in oil/gas markets, versus a financial model relying on a single point (highly uncertain) oil/gas price forecast; (b) ESG - related uncertainties, especially the returns and free cash generation of the company's targeted future asset portfolio of low - carbon businesses.

Our Galp PT of €20 is DCF derived, using a \(9.6\%\) WACC and zero long- term growth, with Brent moving from c. \(\) 81\(in 2024 to a\) \ \(70 / bbl\) long term (flat nominal). The zero growth assumption may well be too cautious in light of its exploration success in Namibia, which will create a new source of long term free cash flow creation. We apply a \(5\%\) ESG discount to capture risks surrounding both the energy transition and the oil price volatility, against our single point Brent forecasts.

Our €14.25 Repsol PT is DCF based. We assume that Brent oil prices decline from c. \(\) 81\(in 2024 to\) \ \(65 / bbl\) in 2025 and 2026, with a long term flat nominal oil price of \(\) 70/ bbl\(with declining refining margins and a gradual recovery / normalisation to chemicals margins. We further assume a WACC of 7.9%. We then apply a 5% discount to the DCF value to arrive at a price target in order to capture both: (1) oil price volatility / cyclicality in what is a single point forecast in a highly volatile market, (2) ESG / energy transition risks of the material diversification attempted to a low carbon portfolio, comprising businesses alien to legacy oil and gas, with different required skills, technologies and competitive pressures.

Our €31.00 Shell PT is DCF derived. We assume Brent oil prices decline from c. \(\) 81\(in 2024 to\) \ \(65 / bbl\) in 2025 and 2026, with a long term flat nominal oil price of \(\) 70/ bbl\(with declining refining margins and an improvement / normalisation to chemicals margins. We further use a 7.8% WACC. We factor in gradual long - term declines in returns and free cash generation under the unfolding energy transition. We apply a 5% discount to the DCF value to arrive at the PT, to capture uncertainties surrounding both the oil market and the energy transition.

TotalEnergies SEThe €65 TotalEnergies PT is DCF derived. We assume Brent oil prices decline from c. \(81 in 2024 to\) 65/bbl in 2025 and 2026, with a long term flat nominal oil price of \(70/bbl\), with declining TTF prices and refining margins, but an improvement in Henry Hub and chemicals margins. We estimate a WACC of \(7.8\%\) . Oil and gas are long- life assets: Total's 2P reserve life is c. 19 years, within which time "peak oil demand" may or may not have occurred. The key offering of large integrated oil company, such as Total is cash/income (dividends) rather than growth, and we believe that discounted free cash flow is appropriate as a valuation methodology. But within an increasingly uncertain geopolitical situation, and an unclear path for transitioning the global energy system to low carbon, we set our 12- month price target on a c. \(5\%\) discount to our estimated DCF valuation, to reflect: (1) the unprecedented volatility in oil/gas markets, versus a financial model relying on a single point oil/gas price forecast; (2) ESG- related uncertainties especially whether the super majors can succeed in replacing legacy oil and gas cash generation and value creation (returns minus WACC) with CFFO from a low carbon, and potentially lower capital intensity portfolio.

BP PLCDownside risks: the biggest risks are (1) oil and gas prices; every \(1 / bbl\) oil price change impacts operating profit by \(340m and every\) 0.10/mmBTU gas price change by \(30m; (2)\) refining margins; each \(1 / bbl\) change impacts EBIT by \(400m; (3)\) the energy transition strategy of building new, low carbon businesses require M&A may continue to be less profitable than legacy Oil & Gas assets. Finally, as this is a dollar reporting company, any material change to FX would also impact the sterling price target.

ENI SpAUpside and downside risks arise from: (1) Oil and gas prices: significant differences above or below our assumptions would lead to material changes to our earnings and valuation. This is a highly volatile, unpredictable space and for a company like Eni which is primarily geared to upstream, with a smaller mid and downstream set of assets than peers. A \(1 / bbl\) oil price change impacts cash flow by €130m. (2) Natural gas market risks: Eni is one of the largest gas companies in Europe; it has ambitious targets for its gas business; a \(1 / mBtu\) spot gas price change impacts free cash flow by €130m. (3) Refining: every \(1 / bbl\) move in margins impacts cash flow by €120m euros. (4) FX: this is a dollar business but Eni reports in euros. Every 5 cent strengthening in the dollar vs the euro impacts cash flows by a negative €540m. (5) Eni's satellite model of giving management autonomy to its low- carbon divisions, and potentially selling small minority stakes, aims to unlock their value. It remains unclear whether this will succeed in abolishing the conglomerate discount which has historically impacted integrated oil company valuations, or whether instead it may add to financial complexity, leading the markets to perceive a reduction of financial predictability.

Galp Energia SGPS SADownside risks to PT: (1) the biggest risks remains the oil price: should this differ substantially from our assumptions (above or below), this would lead to potentially significant changes to our estimates/valuation. For every \(5 / bbl\) change in the Brent oil price, Galp's operating cash flow changes by €85m in the same direction. (2) Galp owns Portugal's only refinery and every \(1 / bbl\) change in refining margins impacts its operating cash flow by €65m; (3) as a dollar business but Euro- reporting company moves in the €/ \(rate are significant: every 5 cent change in FX, impacts Galp's cash flow €80m, which is as large as the impact of a\) 1/ bbl oil price change. (4) Whilst Namibia will be a post- 2030 growth driver for Galp's production, clearly near term risks exist: Galp may be delayed in its attempt to sell half its \(80\%\) interest plus operatorship - especially in light of the guidance that appointing a permanent CEO may take a further six months. Moreover, future drilling results may disappoint; gas may post a challenge to process; delivering a greenfield development in a country with no infrastructure may be subject to the usual large- project delays and cost over- runs.

Repsol SAUpside/Downside risks: Oil and gas prices and refining margins comprise the biggest catalyst and risk: should these prove materially higher or lower than our assumptions, this would lead to material changes in our Repsol estimates and valuation: (1) every \(1 / bbl\) oil price change from our scenario impacts EBIT by €58m p.a and CFFO by €36m; (2) every \(1 / mcf\) Henry Hub gas price change, impacts EBIT by €310m p.a.and CFFO by €144m; (3) and every \(1 / bbl\) refining margin change, impacts EBIT by €248m p.a. and CFFO by €185m; (4) It is a challenge, even for the oil companies themselves, to model/forecast working capital requirements; working capital can move very materially, especially for a large downstream company like Repsol - which increases the risk surrounding market cash flow forecasts versus actuals;

(5) The Peru oil spill of 2022 represents a potentially material financial risk: the country has filed a civil lawsuit against Repsol seeking \(\) 4.5bn\(for environmental damage and local business disruption. (6) an upside risk is the potential press - mentioned disposal of a further minority interest in its renewables business at a higher than expected multiple.

Upside/Downside risks: (1) the key business risk surrounds oil/gas prices; a \(\) 1/bbil\(oil price change impacts earnings (in upstream and LNG) by\) \ \(370m\) and cash flows by \(\) 390m\(; and this is a highly volatile market, as seen in 2020 - 22. A\) \ \(1 / mBTU\) Henry Hub gas price change impacts earnings by \(\) 130m\((\updownarrow\) \updownarrow \(\) 160m\(, whilst a\) \ \(1 / mmBTU\) TTF price change impacts earnings by \(\) 90m\(and CFFO by\) \ \(80m\) . (2) Refining margins: a \(\) 1/bbil\(margin change above or below our forecasts would boost/ cut earnings and cash flows by\) \ \(400m\) . (3) Shell's 'net zero by 2050' strategy is to slowly diversify into new low- carbon businesses whilst preserving profitability. Whilst Shell has de- emphasised renewables, as long as all the new low- carbon markets remain tiny (green hydrogen, etc.), and their technologies have yet to be scaled up to commercial scale, uncertainty will remain over whether these new industries' value added (returns minus WACC) will be similar or inferior to that of the legacy oil and gas business. And the answer to that requires time as the company first needs to establish a track record of actual low- carbon returns, in our view. (4) M&A: Shell needs only c. \(\) 12- 15bn\(of cash on the balance sheet to run its business, and currently has c.\) \ \(40bn\) . This provides it the option, should there be a suitable opportunity, of growing via M&A, be it in the legacy oil/gas business (like Exxon and Chevron mega mergers of 2023), or in the new low- carbon divisions it aspires to build. M&A always carries the risk of value destruction by overpaying/overestimating future cash generation.

Downside risks: (1) The biggest external catalyst and risk are oil and gas prices: should these differ substantially from our assumptions (above or below), this would lead to potentially significant changes to our estimates/valuation. Our rating is predicated on a Brent declining to our long term average of \(\) 70/bbil\(. Every\) \ \(1 / bbil\) oil price change would impact our forecast CFFO by c. \(\) 280m\(. (2) Total is a big refiner: should our refining and chemical margin assumptions prove too high, this would materially impact our estimates/valuation: every\) \ \(10\) /tonne change in refining margin assumptions would impact CFFO forecasts by \(\) 50m\(pa. (3) The company targets for its current\) 10\% \(integrated power returns to grow to\) 12\% \(within 5 years. This comprises mostly renewables but includes CCGTs; however, given the real and extreme pressure on renewable project economics (high interest rates, supply chain issues) in the years since the pandemic, we believe there are risks surrounding the company's ability to continue to both grow scale in its renewables capacity (to the targeted 100GW gross by 2030) as well as to improve its realised returns by 20%.

The Bernstein brand rates stocks based on forecasts of relative performance for the next 12 months versus the S&P 500 for stocks listed on the U.S. and Canadian exchanges, versus the Bloomberg Europe Developed Markets Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (EDM) for stocks listed on the European exchanges and emerging markets exchanges outside of the Asia Pacific region, versus the Bloomberg Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index USD (JP) for stocks listed on the Japanese exchanges, and versus the Bloomberg Asia ex- Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (ASIAX) for stocks listed on the Asian (ex- Japan) exchanges - unless otherwise specified.
The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings:

- Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp- Market-Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-15 pp- Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.

The Autonomous brand rates stocks as indicated below. As our benchmarks we use the Bloomberg Europe 500 Banks And Financial Services Index (BEBANKS) and Bloomberg Europe Dev Mkt Financials Large and Mid Cap Price Ret Index EUR (EDMFI)index for developed European banks and Payments, the Bloomberg Europe 500 Insurance Index (BEINSUR) for European insurers, the S&P 500 and S&P Financials for US banks and Payments coverage, S5LIFE for US Insurance, the S&P Insurance Select Industry (SPSIINS) for US Non-Life Insurers coverage, and the Bloomberg Emerging Markets Financials Large, Mid and Small Cap Price Return Index (EMLSF) for emerging market banks and insurers and Payments. Ratings are stated relative to the sector (not the market).
The Autonomous brand has three categories of ratings:
·Outperform (OP): Stock will outpace the relevant index by more than 10 pp
·Neutral (N): Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-10 pp
·Underperform (UP): Stock will trail the performance of the relevant index by more than 10 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Those denoted as 'Feature' (e.g., Feature Outperform FOP, Feature Under Outperform FUP) are our core ideas. Not Covered (NC)denotes companies that are not under coverage.
For both brands, recommendations are based on a 12-month time horizon.
